Posts.Content: EVISTA (raloxifene) has been shown to be nearly as effective as tamoxifen in preventing breast cancer in high risk women. The problem, of course, is in defining high risk women. Most of the women at high-risk would not have got it anyway. It may not apply to those of us who actually have had breast cancer. It has not been researched head-to- head with tamoxifen or any of the aromatase inhibitors. If you already have had breast cancer, it is unlikely to be used - at least not yet. Hugs. Lesley
Posts.Title: cancer post treatment

Posts.Content: I think I have learned how to fly with kindred spirits. I loved Jonathan Livingstone Seagull when I was younger and I have reread it a couple of times lately. I have found my relationship with people has really shifted. I now see people as those who get it and those who don't. That is, those who can fly and those who cannot. I have drifted away from former friends. I think chemo changes you. It makes you stronger and wiser. And those who don't get it, just don't get it. Hugs. Lesley
Posts.Title: Inspirational saying.....

Posts.Content: Hi Kathi, Well yes. I highly recommend Avalon Organics lotion with lavender. I have just checked the ingredients list - no aloe vera. It smells wonderful and lavender does double duty: the smell helps you sleep and lavender is good for burns. The radiation onc was very impressed with my skin - no burns even though I am very fair. I was not allowed to put it on before the treatment, but I found it very soothing afterwards. No itching. I still use it. The onc thought it worked better than anything she could prescribe. Good luck with the rads. Hugs. Lesley
Posts.Title: Supplements?? What should we do??

Posts.Content: Next Monday. I have marked it on my calendar. Those tattoos are my badges of courage. I asked for butterflies, but all I got was little dots. Hugs. Lesley
Posts.Title: Supplements?? What should we do??

Posts.Content: Oh, yes. I forgot about that. I do drink 4 cups of green tea and 1 cup of rooibos or astragalus tea a day. Strict - yes. But I want to give myself the best chance of keeping this beast away. Whatever the cost. I know - no guarantees. I'm just working at changing the risk. Hugs. Lesley
Posts.Title: Supplements?? What should we do??

Posts.Content: You are doing a lot. First of all, I guess you will need chemo because of your Her status. Yes? The oncs usually advise no supplements during chemo and radiation - in case the supplements protect the cancer cells as well as the body. I think your diet is excellent. I always recommend Diana Dyer's website and book. The URL is www.cancerrd.com I read all research avidly. I think your exercise is terribly important. I have a pedomenter and walk 5 miles outside every day - even in the snow. I take everything you take and a couple more. The vitamin E I take is Isomer E. I know it is controversial (and I am ER+/PR+), but I eat soy every day. Not supplements. Soy milk, miso or tofu. I eat no red meat at all and organic chicken very rarely. I mainly eat salmon (wild caught not farm raised) and sardines. I eat broccoli or cabbage every day. I also eat/drink lowfat yoghurt and lowfat milk (organic). I eat mushrooms almost every day (including Shiitake mushroom at least once a week) and I eat beans every day. I eat about 15 servings of fruit/veggies a day. I eat olives every day and only use olive oil. (Most olive oil you buy is not really olive oil. Put it in the refrigerator. If it doesn't cloud over, it's not olive oil.) I also add wheat germ. wheat bran, rice bran, flax, prunes, 2 Brazil nuts, and other frozen, fresh and dried fruit to my oatmeal. Like Diana, I believe that diet is more important than supplements. Nevertheless, I also take (beyond those you mentioned) astragalus, pycnogenol, Evening Primrose Oil, CoQ10, Alpha Lipoic Acid, B-50. I am sure that I take too many and will probably start cutting down as I get stronger. For now, that is what I find useful. I take melatonin when I can't sleep. Hope some of this/any of this helps. Hugs. Lesley
Posts.Title: Supplements?? What should we do??

Posts.Content: The change in environment can only be a good thing. If nothing else, so you can focus more energy on your health and less on work stress. I am reading a book by Bernie Siegel about cencer patients. I don't like all of what he has to say - parts are really annoying. Anyhow, one part got me really thinking. He claims tha only about 15-20% of patients are willing to make life-style changes after a cancer diagnosis. If this is true, and if it applies to you then CONGRATULATIONS! You are exceptional. Hugs. Lesley
Posts.Title: Supplements?? What should we do??

Posts.Content: When does rads start, Kathi? I want to be with you in spirit. The weirdest thing happened to me during rads. I started to feel terribly nauseous about 2 hours after the first one. Then every day - about 2 hours later. The rad onc said it was not from the rads. But, seriously, 2 hours later only M - F? I knew it had to be. Then I went to see my medical onc. She said that the radiation people never admit that rads can cause nausea - but it can. Here's wishing you smooth sailing with the only hassle being that you have to go every day. Hugs. Lesley
Posts.Title: Supplements?? What should we do??

Posts.Content: I totally agree with you, Tara. That is why I research everything. I only rely on good academic research studies for my information. Medline is my favorite - I subscribe through the university (I have 2 Master's degrees and almost a PhD.) I know that most of the research has been done in test tubes - but we have to take what we can get. If it works in a test tube and will not harm me then I am willing to try it. I think news reports about medicine and drugs are positively dangerously deceptive. I understand statistics and go over all the statistics really carefully. I never rely on information I find on random websites, anecdotal evidence, or books by quacks. (Have you read any of that QUACKERY from Gary Null? I was so annoyed I looked up his PhD - it's one of those that don't require a systematic study. Uh huh.) I would never choose supplements over an FDA approved drug. I know others do, but I would not. I feel it is irresponsible to promote that. I think that is what you were trying to emphasize. And I completely agree. Hugs. Lesley
Posts.Title: Supplements?? What should we do??

Posts.Content: Hi LoVonna, I did not have a fungus on my tongue after chemo (is it thrush?), but I did have a sore that would not heal. (I had terrible mouth sores from the chemo.) I freaked out! I went to the dentist and he prescribed a mouthwash for me. It stained my teeth, but it worked. My mouth was completely healed. It was called chlorhexidine gluconate and you need a prescription for it. Hope you feel better soon. Hugs. Lesley
Posts.Title: mouth fungus

Posts.Content: Oh, Kathi, Honey. I am so so sorry. What a sad loss. I cannot even imagine the pain of losing a child. Warmest Hugs. Lesley
Posts.Title: I'm back, with sad news

Posts.Content: Congrats on your four years. I had a spot on the breast which the onc looked at and laughed and said was nothing. But she did say that if I got a spot that looked red, I was to go back and get it checked. Are you sure this isn't just one of those age spots that we get at a certain age? Check all over your chest. If you have others that look exactly like the one on your breast, they are age spots and quite normal. If this one looks different, I'd go back and check with the doctor just for the peace of mind. Hope it is nothing. Hugs. Lesley
Posts.Title: red spot on breast

Posts.Content: Melanie, I am so very sorry that you have joined us. These ladies have given you excellent advice. Please do contact the nearest large breast center (like JH). I actually do know someone who is 20 years past a diagnosis of Stage IV BC. She is in total remission. I agree Lobular does not show on a mammogram. I was diagnosed with Stage III and live in dread. I really find that exercise helps relieve the anxiety a lot. I walk 5 miles every day - even in Denver. You may need medication to get you through this time. I would not hesitate to ask. Hugs. Lesley
Posts.Title: Stage IV breast cancer - in bones

Posts.Content: Great news about the improvement, Kathy. Have a wonderful Mother's Day. Hugs. Lesley
Posts.Title: A better day for Mother's Day

Posts.Content: Have a very Merry Christmas. This time last year I was in the midst of rads. Now, I treasure every day and especially every Christmas. Hugs. Lesley
Posts.Title: Merry Christmas to All

Posts.Content: Yeoch!!! Kammie that is awful. I am glad you are both recovering. All the best. Hugs. Lesley
Posts.Title: Contamination

Posts.Content: Thank you for the thought-provoking post. Hugs. Lesley
Posts.Title: Contamination

Posts.Content: I know what you mean. We search for causes all the time. But I know that I, for one, really did have no risk factors. Never smoked, or drank. Ate a very healthy diet. Exercised 3-4 times a week. Breast-fed four babies for 2 years each, started my periods at 15, no family history, never been overweight, etc. I never evey took the birth control pill because I did not want to raise my risk unnecessarily. When I spoke to my oncologist about the fact that I had no risks, she shook her head and said that she sees so many patients without risks. I truly believe that while our behavior/genetics is blamed, our environment can be ignored. Hugs. Lesley
Posts.Title: Contamination

Posts.Content: It's a balancing act this, isn't it? We do what we can until our bodies say no. There is not a lot of evidence about Herceptin yet - only that it helps. You may have already had all the Herceptin your body needed. Good luck. FWIW, I think your heart is perfect. :-) Hugs. Lesley
Posts.Title: Don't want to be discouraged

Posts.Content: I would definitely check with the oncologist first. I think there are better and more effective supplements for BC survivors. I take many, but I don't take either of those. I do a lot of research before I decide to take one. Hugs. Lesley
Posts.Title: Resvert and Carnivora? Anybody take these?
